comment_0: Paul did indeed make an error at the end, and the other three Beatles liked it enough that the kept it in.  The phrase Ob-la-di Ob-la-da means "life goes on".  Also, Paul actually heard the phrase from a Nigerian congo player in a group called Bad Manners named Jimmy Anonmuogharan Scott Emuakpor.  Jimmy actually tried to sue him for using that phrase, a lot of events followed, and Jimmy dropped the case after Paul payed the support money that Jimmy owed his ex-wife and they both became close friends afterward.

comment_20:
great song

A song by Paul, it came from the phrase, Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da, that means "life goes on," that Paul heard by a man named Jimmy Anonmuogharan Scott Emuakpor, a Nigerian congo player who played in a group known as Bad Manners. Paul met him in the Bag o' Nails club in Solo, London. When Paul wrote the song, Jimmy Scott was annoyed, citing that he should receive some of the financial rewards for it. McCartney responded by telling him that if he had written any part of it, he would be glad to pay him, but he didn't. Scott sued, and meanwhile, was jailed for refusing to pay support to his ex-wife. Jimmy appealed to Paul to pay his rather large past support payment, which Paul did to help him out, but on the condition that Jimmy drop his case against him over the song. Jimmy did and he and Paul came to be and remained close friends over the years until Scott's death in 1986.

Paul loved this song and made many takes of it, driving the remaining three Beatles' crazy. McCartney wanted it released also as a single, but Lennon hated it and refused to let that happen. Consequently, a Scottish group known as Marmalade recorded it and had a number one hit. There is a mistake in the song where McCartney sang that "Desmond stayed at home and did his pretty face," when it should have been as the other similar line, referring to Molly. The three other Beatles liked the error, and it remained. Desmond has a barrow in the marketplace, Molly is the singer in a band, Desmond says to Molly, girl I like you face

comment_35:
For most of the song, it is just a happy upbeat song, and mostly just about having fun, until you realize that the Beatles established early in the song that indeed Molly is a girl, and that "she is the singer in the band". Then, at the third verse from the bottom, it says:

"Desmond stays at home and does HIS pretty face,
And in the evening SHE's singer with the band."

And since they're Desmond and Molly Jones, we can pretty much guess what this song's underlaying meaning is.

comment_52:
My GF absolutely luvs this song. Me, I really don't like it that much. It's okay.
It's more like a Wings song, kinda like "Hi, Hi, Hi".

I like the fact that John came into the studio stoned & pissed off, then played that piano intro & said "This is how we're gonna do it!" Then John & George make sarcastic jabs @ it, when Paul sings "....lend a hand". then John & George say, "Arm" "Leg".

I do remember being in 2nd grade @ recess when I heard a car go by blasting this song. It was the very first Beatles song I ever heard.
Much later, when the 45rpm came out, a friend of mine bought it. "Ob-la-di..." on the A side & "Helter Skelter" on the B-side. I'd ride my bike over to his house to listen to it. We listened to Helter Skelter over and over! 
I like the Anthology version much better!!!!
comment_53:
This song is ABSOLUTELY about Desmond being, or becoming, a cross-dresser.  The "Desmond stays at home and does his pretty face" lyric in the last stanza should read: "Desmond stays at home and does her pretty face".  The song is about changes that often happen in marriages and how, if the couple wants to be happy, they should endure those changes positively - that life goes on.

As usual, the Beatles are being lyrically sly.

By the way, "bra" is an abbreviation for "brother" and should probably be indicated as such (bra').

comment_57:
This song has been condemned as bong commonplace, doggerel, even boring. But actually it's deeply subversive.,  A friend told me that she thought the final switching places in the lyric of "Happy ever after on the marketplace, Desmond lets the children lend a hand, Molly stays at home and does her pretty face..." to â¦ "Molly lets the children lend a hand.. Desmond stays at home and does his pretty face" was an indication that Molly (the woman) did all the work...but it's weirder than that. The hint of what's to come is what Desmond says to Molly, "Girl, I like your face"...

The truth is that Desmond is a drag queen-- a straight drag queen (they DO exist!). He likes (that is, envies) her face... later, when Desmond is in the marketplace "Molly stays at home and does her pretty face, and in the evening she still sings it with the band"... but when Molly's in the marketplace, "Desmond stays at home and does his pretty face, and in the evening she's a singer in the band"-- and that "she" refers to Desmond, not Molly!  And the jaunty piano riff underlying that last line points it up his stint with the band with his pretty face done up.  Pretty subversive even today, and remarkable for the '60s, which is probably why so few people got it. Desmond and Molly are happy being who they are, however much it flies in the face of expectations.
comment_58: Hey Roger, I got one word for you...WRONG!!
